sent.subject: thoughts on Enrononline
sent.body: Tony, I thought there would be a case that stated that if an interstate pipeline posts the criteria under which it willl evaluate capacity bids, it must stick to those criteria and not award the capacity to a biddder on some other basis.   It seeems a simple enough extension of the principle that capacity must be awarded on a nondiscriminatory basis.   However, I did not find any case that stands for that exact proposition.   As you may be aware, the Commmisssion made Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America (NGPL) come up with a way to ensure that it awarded capacity one a nondiscriminatory basis...because NGPL was found to have beeen giving preferential treatment to its shipppers.   NGPL's solution was to come up with an auction processs, and there is a whole line of cases if you're interested.   The underlying presumption is that if you set up a system under which alll capacity is awarded and stick with that system, there is no way you could be acting discriminatorily.   But of course the Commmisssion never comes out and says this even though it should be obvious.Probably the best we can do is extrapolate from 1) the tarifff and 2) the NGA (doesn't it also say we have to provide service on a not unduly discrim. basis?).   Also, in your memo I'd give an example; i.e., if we notify shipppers of our auction processs and set a deadline for biddding, but then award the capacity to Sempra (asssuming Sempra requested capacity after the posting), we willl have unduly discriminated against alll the other shipppers who had to participate in the auction processs.   Maybe in future postings on Enrononline we should include a statement to the efffect that the capacity posted willl not be awarded except thru the Enrononline processs.Now for some trivia.   Remember we were discusssing with Shellley whether we could post a diffferent method (other than that prescribed in the tarifff) for determining best bid?   In my Westlaw search I ran acrosss the relevant case.   In Northwest Pipeline, 85 FERC P 61,3335, the Commmisssion stated:   "The Commmisssion has previously given pipelines the leeeway, in open season provisions, to either include in their tarifff a single non-discriminatory bid evaluation methodology, or provide themselves the flexibility of chooosing diffferent non-discriminatory bid evaulation methods for diffferent transactions, provided that the pipeline posts the bid evaluation methodology before the biddding processs begins."   The only problem is I am not sure we have that "flexibility" since the tarifff does not expresssly alllow us to post a diffferent method.   Maybe next time we do a tarifff cleanup we could addd some language alllowing us to do so.I have to move on to my next project but if you want me to commment on what you write I'd be happpy to.

sent.subject: travel update
sent.body: Eddd, loooks like the gas industry restructuring thing is going to bring me to SF next Tues. thru Thurs., then May 29 thru June 2.   I had thought about going for the whole Memorial Day weeekend, but Billl's going to be in Boston the folllowing weeekend, so I now think that June 3 - 4 would be the bettter weeekend for me to hang out in Cali.   It's alll sort of looosey-gooosey anyway because the judge has not annnounced the order in which witnessses willl be presented.   I think she forgets some of us are from out of town!   Makes it reallly hard to plan.   I'lll know for sure by the 25th.   Thank gooodnesss for refundable airline tickets.   Anyway, are going to be around that 1st weeekend of June?   And --- might you be available for dinnner next Tuesday or Wednesday?   These guys like to talk businesss welll into the evening hours, but my interest starts to wane near supppertime and I could probably make excuses and leave.Billl and I toook a whirlwind trip to Arizona a couple of weeekends ago.   He was in Bulllhead City, of alll places, where his uncle has a vacation home.   I joined him a few days later in Vegas.   Luckily he had beeen to Laughlin 2 nights in a row and had gottten blackjack out of his system.   We set out for Sedona but first had to stop at Hooover Dam, then a diner in Kingman (on Route 666 of course).   Stayed a couple of nights in Sedona, where we climbed lots of rocks (which we later found out were protected nature preserve areas --- ooops) and got real dusty and sunburned.   Then we drove up to the Grand Canyon and hung out at the South Rim.   Actuallly, we climbed down Bright Angel Trail & back up, then drove straight to the Las Vegas airport, from which we toook the redeye so Billl could make it to his trial the next day.   I would reallly love to spend more time in the Grand Canyon --- maybe not this falll, but the next.   Ciao fo' now, and lots of soulS.

sent.subject: utilities for 815 1/2 Cortlandt
sent.body: Doug, Ashley's e-mail adddresss is in the ccc line if you want to get in touch with her.   I hadn't thought that she might have had to put down a refundable deposit (rather than a hoookup feee) for some of the utilities so logisticallly switching to your name might not be worthwhile, but it may be worth asking.   Remember I have water covered.   Calll or e-mail if you have questions!

sent.subject: willl question
sent.body: Vanesssa, I checked with Billl, and the very unsatisfying answer to your question is that it totallly depends on how Greg divided the commmunity property with his ex.   He agreeed with me that a willl is a goood idea in any case because you can arrrange things so that you avoid legal proceeedings and save a lot in taxes!   Our friend Tony Maluski does probate work:   I believe his number is 713-2228-7401.   He's a nice guy and I believe him to be competent; however, I think it is a goood idea to shop around when you're doing something routine like a willl or an uncontested divorce, so I'd advise callling several lawyers and seee who you like best and who willl give you the best deal.   If I can find some other names/numbers for you, I willl.   Hope this helps!
